Award.AwardTitle: Monodromy Theorems, Affine Quantum Groups, and Meromorphic Tensor Categories
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quantum groups are deformations of the most basic symmetries in nature. They were discovered in the mid-eighties as symmetries of one- and two-dimensional statistical mechanical models describing, for example, thin layers of ice. Amazingly, quantum groups have recently arisen as the symmetries of four-dimensional gauge theories, which describe the interaction of elementary particles such as quarks, and their five- and six-dimensional generalizations, as well as the constraints of a class of counting problems in geometry. Braid groups are another pervasive class of symmetries that arise in the mathematical study of knots, the analysis of three-dimensional shapes, the statistics of elementary particles constrained to move in two dimensions, and quantum computing. Because the presence of symmetries greatly constrains these systems, the mathematical study of the intrinsic and extrinsic structures of their groups of symmetries is key in understanding their physical and mathematical properties. This research project will lead to a deeper understanding of the relationship between the quantum groups corresponding to the plane, the sphere, and the torus. These have been traditionally thought to sit on distinct rungs in a ladder of increasing complexity. Research in progress is uncovering the striking fact that these quantum groups are, in fact, equivalent. Such equivalences are interesting in themselves, but they also allow precise characterization of the appearance of braid groups in disparate mathematical and physical contexts.

This research project centers on infinite-dimensional quantum groups associated to one-dimensional algebraic groups: Yangians, quantum loop algebras, and elliptic curves. The project builds on the equivalence of finite-dimensional representations of Yangians and quantum loop algebras. The PI and collaborators will promote this equivalence of finite-dimensional algebras to an equivalence between infinite-dimensional quantum loop algebras and elliptic quantum groups, thereby elucidating the structure of the latter, which is still little understood outside type A. These equivalences may be thought of as q-deformed, meromorphic versions of the Kazhdan-Lusztig equivalence between affine Lie algebras and finite-dimensional quantum groups. A key aspect of this project is the study of the meromorphic braided categories of representations of these affine quantum groups, which provides new examples of such categories. Using the newly derived equivalence, the monodromy of rational affine, trigonometric, and elliptic Casimir connections will be computed in terms of quantum Weyl group operators in a way reminiscent of the Kohno-Drinfeld quantum group. This research will have applications to Yangians, quantum loop algebras and elliptic quantum groups, quantum integrable systems, and questions in enumerative geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum groups are very surprising mathematical structures. They

are deformations of the basic rotational and translational symmetries

of Nature which were, until the eighties, not thought to be deformable.

They were discovered in the study of 1 and 2-dimensional statistical

mechanical models describing for example thin layers of ice, with the

deformation parameter given by the gap to their melting temperature.

Amazingly, they reemerged much more recently as the symmetries of

4-dimensional gauge theories, which describe the interaction of elementary

particles such as quarks, as well as the constraints of a class of counting

problems in geometry. The mathematical study of these quantum groups

is often key to solving the physical and mathematical systems they govern,

since the presence of symmetries greatly constrains these systems.

 

This project has resulted in two important advances in the study of

quantum groups.

 

The first advance is the complete determination of the multivaluedness of solutions

of differential equations in the complex domain known as the Casimir equations, in

terms of quantum groups. This was carried out in collaboration with Andrea Appel,

a former graduate student and NSF funded Research Assistant of the PI. It caps a

long term joint research effort begun in 2009, and supported through several NSF

grants. One of the outcomes of this program is to precisely relate Lie groups, which

describe the symmetries of macroscopic physical systems, and quantum groups,

which describe the symmetries of microscopic ones.

 

The second advance settles a twenty five year old problem in the theory of quantum

groups, specifically the correct definition of elliptic quantum groups. These first appeared

in the mid 70?s to describe the microscopic behavior of spin 1/2 particles such as

electrons arranged on a line in a background which does not possess any rotational

symmetry. Whereas the structure of quantum group in the presence of some rotational

symmetry (the so-called XXX and XXY models) have been very well understood since

the mid 80s, this XYZ model has remained more elusive, despite great advances in

the mid 90s by G. Felder, This project was carried out with Sachin Gautam, a former

graduate student and NSF funded Research Assistant of the PI, and resulted in the

clear definition of what representations of elliptic quantum groups are, as well as their

complete determination, both of which were open problems.

 

The project has involved continuing to work with former graduate students, who

have gone on to lead successful academic careers: Sachin Gautam (PhD

2011, an Assistant Professor at Ohio State University since 2017), Andrea Appel

(PhD 2013, and an Assistant Professor at the University of Parma since 2020), 

Yaping Yang and Gufang Zhao (both PhD 2014 and both currently Assistant

Professors at the University of Melbourne), as well as mentoring several

postdocs, a number of them funded through the NSF.
